turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So you're saying it wasn't like that at all.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Not exactly. I mean, there was more to it than I told you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Christ. You didn't just see what happened. They dropped the package on the ground and you picked it up.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yeah, I picked it up.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: And started to run.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: And started to run.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good thinking.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's just it. I didn't think. I just did it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You have one hell of a knack for getting into trouble, don't you?  So how much does it come to?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Six thousand dollars. Five thousand eight hundred and fourteen dollars, to be exact.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So you robbed the robbers, and now the robbers are after you.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That's it. In a nutshell.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, well, you have to be nuts to do what you did. If you want my opinion, you should give this money back to the Creeper. Just give it back and tell him you're sorry.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: No way. There's no way I'm giving that money back. It's my money now.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: A lot of good it will do you if the Creeper finds you.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: That money is my whole future.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Keep up with that attitude, and you won't have a future.  Seventeen is a hell of an age to die. Is that what you want?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: So you lost the job. Is that what you're telling me? He just up and fired you?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It was more complicated than that. There was a reason.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It wasn't my fault.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If you don't tell me what happened, how do you expect me to know that? I need facts, not opinions.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: The water was dripping, see... I turned it off, but it was still dripping, and then Auggie had to go out, and so I left the back room ... And later on ... well, later on ... when Auggie came back ... the whole place was flooded. His Cuban cigars got all messed up ... You know, soaked through ... just when he was about to sell them ... to these rich guys in suits....

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Cuban cigars. You mean he had some hanky-panky going with those guys?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I suppose so. He never told me about it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No wonder he was angry.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: He was out five thousand bucks, he said.... He kept saying it over and over.... Five thousand bucks down the drain.... He wouldn't stop.... Five thousand bucks, five thousand bucks.... He was like out of his mind with those five thousand bucks....

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Here's what you're going to do. You're going to open up your backpack, take out your bag of money, count out five thousand dollars, and hand it over to Auggie.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: What are you talking about?  You can't be serious.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm serious, all right. You've got to square it with Auggie. Since you won't give the money back to the Creeper, you can use it to make things right with Auggie. That's probably better anyway. Better to keep your friends than to worry about your enemies.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I'm not going to do it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You'll do it, all right. You fuck up, you've got to undo the damage. That's how it works, buster. If you don't do it, I'm going to throw you out of here. Do you understand me? If you don't pay Auggie what you owe him. I'm finished with you.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I pay Auggie, and I've got nothing. Eight hundred bucks and a ticket to Shit City.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Don't worry about it. You've got friends now, remember? Just behave yourself, and everything will work out.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Fuck you, too, you white son-of-a-bitch.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Good. I'm glad that's settled!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Hi, kid.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Wow. They sure did a job on you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Research. I worked the scene right into my story.  That makes the medical bills one hundred percent tax deductible.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: We came here to deliver some clean laundry.

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: It's all right. I really do know them.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If it doesn't make any difference, why not just say it?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: I was going to tell him ... but in my own time. In my own time... .

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Like it or not, Cyrus, that's my name. Cole. Just like yours.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Now ask him who his mother was.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, give him another one. And I'll take a cup of coffee while you're at it.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Hot coffee or iced coffee?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Do you have real iced coffee, or do you just pour hot coffee over some ice cubes?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Everything is real in here, honey.  As real as the color of my hair.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'll take the iced coffee.  You only live once, right?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: If you're lucky.  Then again, it depends on what you call living.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't mean to pry, but I see a kid walking around with a big knapsack on his back, and I begin to wonder if all his worldly possessions aren't stowed in there. Are you in some kind of trouble or what?

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: How do you want that cooked?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Medium rare, please.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Fries?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yes, please.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: Lettuce and tomato?

turns.speaker: RASHID
turns.text: Yes, please.

turns.speaker: WAITRESS
turns.text: You want another one of these, too?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Don't know how long it's take to get a charge...

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Keep it tonight.  We'll catch fish. I'll see ya back on the docks...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Seven acres.  I'm wonderin' what you'd pay for 'em.  Just curious, is all.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: What are you sellin' 'em for? Why don't we start there.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: The battery's in, that's done with.  Besides, you'd do the same for m...

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: ...<u>might</u> do the same.  I have to warn you 'bout that, chief.  I'm not screwed together like I used to be.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: I am a bastard.  I'm a big Hun Nazi son of a bitch.  And I still got your bamboo fishing rod.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Oh, yeh?

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: Hid it from my mom.  Caught a mess a sea runs.  Damn thing's still in my closet.

turns.speaker: CARL
turns.text: $1200 an acre, that's what I paid Ole, won't take a dime less.  You got no choice on that.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Didn't say I was buyin' did I? What you want down?  Just bein' curious, is all.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So the blood on the gaff was not fish blood at all.  It was <u>human</u>, yes?  Type B positive.

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: Carl Heine's type.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: But you can't say with any certainty that the blood was his.

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: No, but as I say, the type is rare. Ten percent of Caucasian males.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: And the blood could <u>not</u> have belonged to defendant.  Seeing that his type is O negative.

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: That's obvious.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You scraped the dried blood from the <u>butt</u> of the gaff.  Where a fella's <u>hand</u> goes.  And what did you see under your microscope, besides the B positive blood and the wood scrapings...?

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: Bits of blood and wood.  What else would there be?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: No bits of bone, no particles of scalp, no strands of hair?

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: None.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Well, if the blood got <u>onto</u> the gaff by crushing a man's skull...

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: I'm a hemotologist, sir, I was asked only t...

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: You don't.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: With no bone or scalp or hair present.  Would it be more probable that the blood came from crushing a man's skull...

turns.speaker: DR. WHITMAN
turns.text: I'm a hemotologist, not a detective.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: ...or from the cut on his hand. Which is more probable?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Him and his folks and two brothers and two sisters worked our land. Lived in a picker's cabin at first.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So the defendant knew the deceased, your son, even then.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: They fished t'gether.  Went to school. Carl Junior treated him like a white person.  Like any friend.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: But back in '34, Japanese-born could not <u>own</u> land.  So...?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Carl held it <u>for</u> 'em.  Called it a lease.  They make payments every June and December...

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Why?  If they could never take title.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Their kids was born here.  So when the oldest, that one there, was twenty...last payment gets made, and he could own it.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Now defendant's father had also died by that point.  Where was the defendant?  When you sent his family their equity.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: In the war.  Europe, I believe. They could hardly send him to the Pacific, could they?

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And when he came home.  Did he write you about this?  Or phone, perhaps.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Just showed up at my door, big as life and twice as mean.  Wanted to talk to my son.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: What do you mean by 'dirty looks'?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Well.  Every time I see him in town or somewhere, he's starin' at me with these narrow eyes. Givin' me his mean face.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: When your son came back from the war, what did he say about all this?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: That he'd keep an eye on Miyamoto. Watch out for him.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Did he see some <u>danger</u> from defen...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Just three questions.  The Miyamoto family bought your seven acres for $4500?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Tried to.  Defaulted on their payments.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Second question.  What did Ole Jurgensen pay you per acre?

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: A thousand.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So that makes what would have been $4500 into $7000, doesn't it?  If you sent the equity back, you had a profit of $2500.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: Is that your third question?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: ETTA
turns.text: You done your math right.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now, Mister Gi...

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Unwritten rule of the sea.  We don't bother each other, stick to ourselves. Ask anybody.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now if you wanted to kill a man. Think you'd try boarding against his will, and hitting him with a fishing gaff?

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: It's a joke.  Maneuver up to Carl's boat?  Tie your lines fast?  Come aboard?  All against Carl's will? It's the stupidest suggestion I ever heard of.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: I'm sorry about that.  It wasn't mine in the first place.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: So the fishing gaff method wouldn't make sense?

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Couldn't get on the boat.  I'd just <u>shoot</u> the feller.  <u>Then</u> tie up, throw him inta th' drink.  And skip bein' the first gill-netter in history to make a successful forced boarding.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Now the sheriff believed that the D-6 battery in Carl's well was Carl's own spare.  Even though it was too large f...

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: No sense to have <u>any</u> at all., even the right size.  It's like having an extra battery in the trunk of your car.  Nobody does.

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Boat has two batteries.  Lose one you run off the other til morning. Carl musta lost both, so Miyamoto there gave him one a his.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Course, if Carl lost both batteries, dead in the water, his radio wouldn't work.  So how would he signal for help?

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Compressed air horn, most likely. Hope to God some man hears you in that fog.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: All right, what if the defendant <u>heard</u>?  So Carl <u>let</u> him aboard, to help.  And <u>then</u> the fishing gaff?

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: You mean Miyamoto followed him out there, and sucker-punched him?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Well, what if?

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Now, how is Miyamoto gonna know in <u>advance</u>?  That Carl loses two batteries.  Must happen once ever' 20 years or so.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Gillanders.  Thank you for coming down, in this cold weather.

turns.speaker: GILLANDERS
turns.text: Well, it does seem mighty warm in here.  Specially for Mr. Hooks.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I said 'excited'.  Not agitated, he was excited in the sense of being overjoyed.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: You were...overjoyed yourself, to hear the news?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Happy for him.  And relieved.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So, then, you...and your husband... must have called friends, relatives, to tell them the amazing news.  Yes?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: We hear how Carl...passed away. Only a few hours later.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Your husband returned at, what, seven o'clock?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Closer to eight.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So, five hours.  Plenty of time for a call.  He was 'excited', you say. In the sense of being 'overjoyed'.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: You thought the deceased might... break his promise?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Of course not.  We're just not quick to run and boast.  In case something went wrong.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And then, something did.  Carl Heine was found dead.  With his head crushed.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Yes, and then, what was there to call about?  Everything was up in the air.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Up in the air?  Was <u>that</u> your reaction?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: We discussed that.  And decided not to.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Because the facts could be misconstrued as murder.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: But if truth was on your side, whatever were you worried about?

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Trials aren't only about truth, Mr. Hooks.  Even though they should be.  They're about what people <u>believe</u> is true.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So you hid the truth.  Deliberately.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: We were afraid.  Silence seemed better.  To come forward seemed like a mistake.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Well, it seems to me...

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Doesn't it seem to <u>you</u>, Mrs. Miyamoto, that your mistake was in being deceitful?  Concealing information during the course of a sheriff's investigation.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: It seems human.  To me.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Question withdrawn, you may step down.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: You're implying th...

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: I said.  No further questions.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: He's still got a good grip.  We need to dig more.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: At school, she kept mostly to the Japanese kids, and sort of ignored me.  As if all of our times alone together...in the hollow cedar, everywhere...were a secret.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: I told myself that was good.  That it made our friendship special.  And didn't mean she was ashamed of it. Necessarily.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Easy.  Slow is best.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: The best part was that there was a 'this'.  To debate the wrongness of.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Your friends would.  Your dad would kill me with a machete.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: We're Japanese, not Mexican, Ishmael. He'll slice you up with a ceremonial sword.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: My mom.  Would be the problem.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Why?  We're only talking.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I can just feel my spirits soar.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Well, I don't do it for just anybody.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: There can't be any wrong in this, Ha...

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I lie to my parents every day. And every night.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: My father can't get our money from the bank.  We have a few dol...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: It'll be over soon.  I can get you money.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: It's just Pearl Harbor.  People are a little crazy, right n...

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Look at my face.  It's the face of the people who did that.  My father hardly speaks English.  We're in bad trouble, you have to see that.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: We all expect the world to be fair. As if we have some right t...

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I don't mean everyone.  Just people who can do things because they can arrest people or convict them.  Or run a newspaper.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: I couldn't say anything.  I just stood there, hating her.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I'm sorry about your arm.  Kabuo and I.  Are very sor...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: The Japs did it.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: I'm married, Ishmael.  It isn't right for us to be alone.  People will t...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: There's no one here, and I've <u>got</u> to talk to you.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: You have to hear this, I can never touch you, Ishmael.  Not once, not ever.  There's no half- way.  As much as I know it hurts you, you have to let this go.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Look, I <u>want</u> to forget you, I do. I think if you hold me, just this once, I can walk away and never speak to you again.

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: Did you write that column?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: I did.  But the jury won't s...

turns.speaker: HATSUE
turns.text: It's not for the.  They only get to convict him.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You don't believe in God anymore.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Agnostics don't believe or disbelieve, Ma.  We just don't pretend we know.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: I felt Milholland's report in my pocket.  And wondered why I wasn't telling her.  Telling someone. What I'd found.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: You've been busy with that trial, I suppose.  Such a travesty...

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: They only arrested that poor soul because he's Japanese.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Seattle boys think he's guilty.  They say the evidence is rock solid.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: They're not his neighbor, like you are.  He is a husband, a father, he risked his <u>life</u> for <u>their</u> country. The same as you.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Those aren't the facts that matter.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Your father fought at Belleau Wood, it took him years to get over it.  Nightmares, tears, b...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: ...but he found you.

turns.speaker: MAPLES
turns.text: They were Japanese-American boys, yes sir.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And you were generally experienced in training men for hand-to-hand combat.

turns.speaker: MAPLES
turns.text: It was my specialty, sir, I trained several thousand over the years.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So.  Wide cross-section of men to evaluate.  And the day that the defendant volunteered for this... demonstration.  Did you find him eager?

turns.speaker: MAPLES
turns.text: More than eager.  He was out to make a point.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Well, what then, sergeant?

turns.speaker: MAPLES
turns.text: What else?  I had the boy teach me kendo.  Including...the importance of the bow.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And your evaluation of the defendant?  Could he kill a much larger man with a fishing gaff? So quickly, there would be no sign of struggle?

turns.speaker: MAPLES
turns.text: Oh, in a heartbeat.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And you weren't there, when the coroner examined the wound.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Nossir.  I'd gone to tell the wid... to tell Mrs. Heine.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So, no...immediate suspicion, no...general talk of enmity between the two.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: These are fishermen, Alvin.  They don't talk at all to each other and less to me.  Specially gossip.

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: ...comes off third cleat from the stern, port side.  And it's brand new.  Unlike the rest.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And the next one...?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: From Carl Heine's boat.  All his were like this one, three-strand manila, new condition, braided in loops.  Not bowlined like Miyamoto's.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And the last...?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Found on Carl's boat, too.  Starboard side, second cleat from the stern. But it doesn't match Carl's lines. It matches Miyamoto's.  perfect.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: So if defendant had tied up to deceased's boat.  With that last one.  Would those cleats have lined up?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: You bet.  And if Miyamoto there had been in a hurry to cast off, he coulda left this line behind on Carl's boat.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And replaced it later with the new one.  That's your inference?

turns.speaker: MORAN
turns.text: Pretty darn clear.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: ...so when the sheriff returned, you showed him the injury to the deceased's head.

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: He said, 'Could it be somebody hit him?'  And I said, 'You want to play Sherlock Holmes, here?'

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Did you say more?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: I said that if I was playing Sherlock Holmes...I'd maybe look for a... Japanese person.  With a bloody gun- butt.  A right-handed fella, to be precise.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And why.  Is that?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Well, I was a doctor in the Jap theater, in the war.  I saw those kendo wounds, <u>many</u> times.  Looked exactly like this one.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Could you tell me what 'kendo' is?

turns.speaker: WHALEY
turns.text: Japanese stick-fighting.  They're trained as kids, y'know.  To kill with sticks.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: As peculiar as a struggle between a 235 pound man, and an assailant strong enough to subdue him...that leaves only a <u>single</u> overturned <u>cup</u> in its wake?

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Objection, asking the witness to speculate.

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: My gosh, Alvin, was I supposed to object every time you did that?

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Objection.  Asking witness to speculate about deceased's state of mind.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: All right.  What did your son <u>say</u> to that effect?

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: You're a hard man to trust, sir. You sit before us, with no expression, keeping a poker f...

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Objection!

turns.speaker: NELS
turns.text: Your Honor, <u>all</u> of this is speculation.  Including Mr. Hooks' dramaturgy about the defendant issuing a false distress call.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Tht was summation, Your H...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Maybe it went.  Where Carl went. Over the side.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Objection!  Speculation.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: <u>Everything</u> had to happen <u>just</u> right.  For your little story to fly.  I mean, a blond hair could be on that gunnel for a <u>lot</u> of reasons.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: I'm sorry, was there a question in there?

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Well, the freighter.  The twine. The blood.  The knife.  The cup. The watch.  The second battery. The phantom lantern.  The fishing gaff.  The cracked gunnel.  The skull wound.  The blond hair.  That's <u>eleven</u> things...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Twelve.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And since you confess this is all pure guesswork.  What is your expertise, sir, are you a detective of sorts?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: My expertise.  Is that I'm a journalist.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Then putting them together.  So truth is revealed.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: But isn't the <u>truth</u> that there are <u>several</u> other ways to explain <u>each</u> of these twelve pieces.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Your line of work.  You must meet a lot of men play fast and loose with the truth.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Like you couldn't believe.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Greedy.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: He didn't want to lose any more.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: I asked you a question, you're writing a tract, h...

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: That's how journalists.  Answer questions.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And I wouldn't blame these good people if they were a mite resent- ful.  At a tactic that insults their intelligence.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: That's curious.  I was <u>appealing</u> to their intelligence.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: <u>Were</u> you, sir?  Can you <u>prove</u> one word of all your fancy story?

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: No, sir, I can't.  Not beyond a reasonable doubt.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Robbed.  He was angry.

turns.speaker: OLE
turns.text: Oh, yeh.  He said someday he would get his land back.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Mr. Jurgensen.  Did he offer to <u>buy</u> the seven acres from you?

turns.speaker: OLE
turns.text: Oh, yeh.  But this is nine year ago, I had my healt, I wasn't wantin' to sell.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: And then your stroke came this summer.  And you put your property on the market, I believe you said September 7.  Which, remember, is <u>eight</u> days before Carl Heine died. And who comes Spetember 7, wanting to buy?

turns.speaker: OLE
turns.text: Carl Heine came.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: But Carl was a fisherman.  And successful at it.

turns.speaker: OLE
turns.text: He said he didn't want that life no more.  He'd been saving to buy a farm.  He was sorry I got sick. But pretty excited to get back his father's place.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: As my wife testified, we were considering it.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Actually, she said you had decided. Decided <u>not</u> not come forward.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Sheriff said right off, I was under suspicion.  I didn't have a lawyer...

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: But even <u>after</u> you had an attorney.  You still claimed to know <u>nothing</u>.  Claimed <u>not</u> to have seen Carl. Am I correct?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Yes.  Initially.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Well, 'initially' is an interesting word, sir.  You'd <u>been</u> arrested, you <u>had</u> a lawyer, and you <u>still</u> claimed ignorance!

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I should have told everything right away.  I know that now, and I regret it.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Should have told 'everything'. Meaning, you should have told the <u>truth</u>.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: My apologies.  Do you regret not telling the truth?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I have told the truth.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: You mean, this morning.  The new story, the battery story. That one is the truth?  That's a question, sir.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: I see.  Now what happened the day Carl Heine was found?  Before your arrest.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I slept til one-thirty, when my wife woke me up with the news.  We talked for a few hours.  I left at six and went straight to my boat.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Didn't go anywhere else?  No errands, no purchases?  Just straight to the boat.  That's the truth.

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HOOKS
turns.text: Well, the sheriff found <u>two</u> batteries in your well.  If you left one with Carl Heine, how is that possible?

turns.speaker: KABUO
turns.text: I had a spare battery in my shed. I brought it down, and put it in just before the sheriff showed up.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: You have the night watch?  On the radio.

turns.speaker: LEVANT
turns.text: Since September.  Last guys got transferred.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: And you keep the records, or contribute to 'em.

turns.speaker: LEVANT
turns.text: Shorthard the radio transmis- sions, write 'em up, file 'em in a cabinet.  Nobody ever looks. Just take up space.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: How long you have this detail?

turns.speaker: LEVANT
turns.text: Me and Smoltz came on dogwatch September 16.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: You mean, early morning the 16th?

turns.speaker: LEVANT
turns.text: No, night of the 16th, morning the 17th.  We replaced two guys named Miller and Milholland.

turns.speaker: LEVANT
turns.text: They got transferred that day. Out to Cape Flattery.

turns.speaker: ISHMAEL
turns.text: Some seaman's loast report. Stuffed in a cabinet, good as lost forever.  No one knows.
